Well, in normal aging, in terms of--if I could use that word, and that's kind of a controversial term, normal aging--but in normal or usual aging, there are measurable changes in memory function that are actually evident, even in the 30s and 40s.
But in terms of pathological changes in memory, of course, the most common being Alzheimer's disease, this is typically--has onset of symptoms in the late 60s and early 70s.
There are some much rarer genetic variants with an earlier onset, but those are really just a very small fraction of the overall disease.
Talking with Dr. Aaron Nelson, author of the ""Harvard Med School Guide to Achieving Optimal Memory,"" co-authored with Susan Gilbert.

For example, we live in a very stressful world.

Actually, at very high and sustained levels, stress has--we know can cause actual physical and physiologic damage to structures in the brain that are important for memory.
But at mild or moderate levels, stress actually can help memory function, believe it or not, because it kind of alerts you.
It gets you to pay attention to something.
It gets you to sort of label an event or an experience as important and worth remembering.

Absolutely.
Sleep is critical for what we call consolidation, which is a process by which memory is etched into storage.
And there's been some fascinating research by some of my colleagues at the Medical School that looks at--and I think actually you had Bob Stickgold on at one point...

...who looks at the role of sleep in learning and consolidation across time.
The other--I think you were mentioning snoring.
That brings to mind obstructive sleep apnea, which is a very common and underdiagnosed condition that can fragment sleep and cause increased--decreased daytime alertness.
And again, you get that kind of a front-end problem with memory, where people are just not as attentive, don't absorb things and, therefore, don't remember them as well.
Another thing we hear a lot about, more people now are aware of their parents or grandparents having Alzheimer's disease.
Does that mean you're going to automatically get it yourself?
Not at all.
In fact, the majority of Alzheimer's disease is sporadic.
It doesn't have at least an obvious genetic connection, a familial connection.
Certainly having a relative with Alzheimer's disease does increase your risk, but it's not anything like the type of genetic determination that we see with other illnesses.
The genetics of Alzheimer's disease are extremely complex.
We don't really have it worked out yet, but at this point, having a relative with Alzheimer's disease does not absolutely seal your destiny as having it yourself.
